sn47.29:4.1: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn47.29:4.2: Now at that time the householder Sirivaḍḍha was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn47.29:4.5: and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:
sn47.29:4.6: ‘Sir, the householder Sirivaḍḍha is sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn47.29:4.7: He bows with his head to your feet.’
sn47.29:4.9: ‘Sir, please visit him at his home out of compassion.’”
sn47.29:4.10: “Yes, sir,” that man replied. He did as Sirivaḍḍha asked.
sn47.29:5.1: Then Venerable Ānanda got dressed in the morning and, taking his bowl and robes, went to the home of the householder Sirivaḍḍha,
sn47.29:5.2: sat down on the indicated seat,
sn47.29:5.4: “Householder, I hope you’re coping; I hope you’re getting better. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing,
sn47.29:5.5: that its fading, not growing, is apparent.”
sn47.29:5.6: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright.
sn47.29:5.7: The pain is terrible and growing, not fading,
sn47.29:5.8: its growing, not fading, is apparent.”
sn47.29:6.2: ‘I’ll meditate by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.29:6.3: I’ll meditate on an aspect of feelings …
sn47.29:6.5: principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.’
sn47.29:7.1: “These four kinds of mindfulness meditation that were taught by the Buddha are found in me, and I embody them.
sn47.29:7.2: For I meditate by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.29:7.3: I meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.29:7.5: principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.29:7.6: And of the five lower fetters taught by the Buddha, I don’t see any that I haven’t given up.”
sn47.29:7.8: You have declared the fruit of non-return.”
